device_models: Microsoft Kinect; Samsung Galaxy SII, 65-inch Panasonic screen with 1920x1080 resolution
use_cases_desc: Cross-device content movement from a handheld device to a larger screen. The use case is not clearly mentioned in the paper, but authors cite public display interaction in their related work.
contribution_desc: The paper contributes results from a comparative study comparing four cross-device interaction techniques (Pinch, Swipe, Throw, and Tilt) for cross-device object movement. Authors are looking at the effectiveness, efficiency, and error size/rate in cross-device content movement from a handheld device (i.e. Samsung Galaxy SII) to a large screen (i.e. 65-inch Panasonic screen with 1920x1080 resolution).
tracking_characteristic: Tracking users only; Inside-out tracking; Outside-in tracking
crossdevice_def:
The authors don't define cross-device interaction themselves, but they cite Jun Rekimoto as one of the pioneers who was looking into "multi-computer user interfaces." He apparently "argued that dedicated interaction techniques would be needed to overcome the boundaries among devices in multiple-computer environments."

Rekimoto, J. 1998. February. Multiple-Computer User Interfaces: A cooperative environment consisting of multiple digital devices. In International Workshop on Cooperative Buildings (pp. 33-40). Springer Berlin Heidelberg.
